DataElement.preferredName: Ipsilateral Breast Malignant Neoplasm Histologic Assessment Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The type related to the histologic assessment of a malignant neoplasm in the ipsilateral breast.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Ipsilateral Breast Malignant Neoplasm Histologic Assessment
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Information related to the histologic assessment of a malignant neoplasm in the ipsilateral breast.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the same side of the body.:One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.:Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.:Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: Having to do with the same side of the body.
One of two hemispheric projections of variable size situated in the subcutaneous layer over the pectoralis major muscle on either side of the chest.
Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.origin: NCCTG CRF:North Central Cancer Treatment Group Case Report Form
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Changed from CTEP to Alliance for by script Fri Oct 25 15:25:44 EDT 2013

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Marked by a tendency to spread especially into healthy tissue.

Concepts.definition: Marked by a tendency to spread, especially into healthy surrounding tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts.  It is also known as DCIS.  There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane.  Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis.  The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

Concepts.definition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (beh-NINE) Not cancerous; does not invade nearby tissue or spread to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: For neoplasms, a non-infiltrating and non-metastasizing neoplastic process that is characterized by the absence of morphologic features associated with malignancy (e.g., severe atypia, nuclear pleomorphism, tumor cell necrosis, and abnormal mitoses). For other conditions, a process that is mild in nature and not dangerous to health.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.: Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.: A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state.

Concepts.definition: An operation in which a term denies or inverts the meaning of another term or construction.
Recognized, familiar, or within the scope of knowledge.
A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the results of evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
